awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: What Controls the Transfer of Diatom Organic Matter to age-0 Pollock Prey in the Bering Sea Ecosystem?
awd_abstract_narration:
The highly productive and economically important Walleye Pollock commercial fishery of the Bering Sea depends on poorly understood food web pathways.  Primary producers of organic carbon, notably diatoms, are consumed by large crustacean zooplankton, which, in turn, are consumed by juvenile pollock.  The dominant paradigm for the system suggests that understanding changes in the biomass of large crustacean zooplankton can help estimate the survival of juvenile pollock; however, recent data show two orders of magnitude uncertainty in the carbon demand of large crustacean zooplankton.  Such uncertainties impact the ability to manage the fishery.  A revised model for the system has been proposed that involves consideration of both the quantity and quality of organic matter produced by diatoms and how this would constrain support for the commercial fishery.  Before investing in a major field effort to test this approach, this project will assess the expected magnitude of change and associated errors, for diatom organic matter production, including the individual terms that are used to estimate it, i.e. abundance, growth rate, and cell carbon.  This effort will be based on laboratory experiments and historical data analysis.  

The project will contribute to STEM workforce development through partial support for the training of a post-doctoral associate.  Undergraduates would be entrained into the science through an REU program at Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences and through the Colby College Semester at Bigelow program.  K-12 outreach will be facilitated through participation in the successful and long-standing Dauphin Island Sea Lab Discovery Hall program.  Outreach to the general public will be accomplished through a blog, Bigelow?s Café Scientifique, and the Bigelow newsletter.  The long-term goal for the research that this project would initiate is improved mechanistic and predictive models for commercial fisheries management.

There is no consensus on the mechanistic relationship of where carbon from the lower trophic levels goes in the Bering Sea ecosystem, hence simple proportionality relationships between primary production and fisheries are used routinely. Bottom-up control on age-0 walleye pollock prey, i.e. large crustacean zooplankton (LCZ), could help constrain this coupling between the primary producers and pollock fishery, but there is a two-order-of-magnitude uncertainty in the LCZ carbon demand based on estimates from the Bering Sea Ecosystem Study (BEST). A new conceptual model is required and this project will begin to refine the issue by focusing on diatoms, which have a less patchy distribution than LCZ and are a key prey item of LCZ.  A major knowledge gap exists in the understanding of the magnitude of diatom loss processes; the logical next step to understanding the fundamental linkage between primary production and fisheries in the eastern Bering Sea is to answer: what is the proportion of diatom primary production available for supporting higher trophic organisms and with which biogeochemical variables does this covary?  Before testing this approach in a field setting, the expected magnitude of change and associated error for diatom organic matter production, including the individual terms that go into that estimate (i.e. abundance, growth rate, cell carbon), must be understood.  This project will combine culture studies using diatoms isolated from high-latitude regions with literature and BEST program data to meet this initial objective.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes:  OCE-1603605, OCE-1603460

Southeastern Bering Sea fisheries are responsible for roughly half of all landings in the U.S.  This ecosystem has been shown to be responsive to recent oscillations between multi-year warm and cold periods.  For example, during warm periods, the abundance of small zooplankton increased and was associated with decreased survivorship of juvenile Pollock.  How phytoplankton, specifically diatoms, at the base of the food web respond to these changes in climate state, and thus the impacts on carbon and energy flow through the ecosystem is not known.  The focus of this project was to conduct laboratory experiments to better understand carbon and nutrient content in diatoms grown under environmentally relevant temperatures, and to measure growth and grazing rates for diatoms, and grazing rates for other phytoplankton.  The field survey was conducted by partnering with the Arctic Shelf Growth, Advection, Respiration and Deposition (ASGARD) cruise in the northern Bering Sea and Chukchi Sea during 5 - 28 June 2017 (Chief Scientist:  Seth Danielson, University of Alaska Fairbanks); this project supported two vessel days.

Laboratory experiments showed that cold-water diatoms consistently were more carbon and nutrient rich that our expectations from diatoms at more tropical latitudes.  This same disparity, higher elemental content for low-temperature adapted diatoms, was also observed for phosphorus and silicon.  Moreover, these diatoms were more carbon and nutrient rich than non-diatom species of similar size grown at similar temperatures.  This observation suggests that changes in phytoplankton communities away from diatoms to other flagellated phytoplankton will negatively impact energy flow in the Bering Sea ecosystem and likely other polar systems too.  In addition, these data suggest that even if diatoms are not displaced by other species, they will be less carbon and nutrient rich due to warming temperatures (i.e. reduced element per unit biovolume).  These results identify multiple mechanisms by which changes in climate may negatively impact carbon and energy flow to higher trophic levels via impacts on the phytoplankton community.

Diatom growth was estimated in a novel way by applying the laboratory-based allometric equations to the ASGARD diatom productivity measurements.  Quantification of total silica production can be a metric to estimate diatom contribution to primary and new production; however, estimating growth has been problematic due presence of detritus (i.e. normalizing to total particulate silica underestimates true diatom growth from silica measurements, this is similar to issues in normalizing C or N uptake to POC or PON bulk measurements).  Normalizing silica production to diatom biovolume-derived living-cell-associated silica resulted in unrealistic values when using allometric equations from low latitudes but normalizing using the cold-water diatom allometry (derived from our field) gave realistic values considering the temperature.  Additionally, these diatom growth rates during ASGARD matched up with a survey of literature measuring diatom growth in culture and field conditions.  Applying these same laboratory results to previous polar literature (e.g. JGOFS AESOPS project in 1997 and 1998) demonstrated the diatom biomass was underestimated due to non-polar diatom allometric equations not accounting for low-temperature diatoms having high elemental density. 

Field experiments to quantify grazing rates on phytoplankton showed that small phytoplankton, primarily not diatoms, were heavily and consistently grazed, while larger diatoms were not.  Out of 26 separate experiments during ASGARD, grazing on large-sized phytoplankton (e.g. diatoms) by microzooplankton was only quantifiable in 14 experiments (54%) whereas smaller phytoplankton (non-diatoms) were quantifiably grazed in 23 experiments (88%). Among those experiments where grazing was successfully quantified, larger phytoplankton growth could have been consumed entirely by microzooplankton in 7 experiments, whereas it consumed ~25% of growth in the other 7.  For smaller phytoplankton, in 13 experiments microzooplankton grazing could consume all growth and in 10 other experiments this averaged 63% of growth.  Funneling primary production through microzooplankton increases the number of trophic steps in the food web.  These observations suggest that changes in phytoplankton community away from diatoms will likely lead to additional losses of carbon and nutrient flow further limiting carbon and energy for fisheries. 

Overall, this project identified two new mechanisms and provided additional data on a third describing how changes in phytoplankton communities with warming temperatures may restrict the flow of carbon and nutrients to higher trophic levels in one of the ocean?s most productive ecosystems.


Last Modified: 11/27/2019
Modified by: Jeffrey W Krause
